<doc url="https://www.androidheadlines.com/2019/10/top-10-best-high-value-smartphone-budget-october-2019.html" parent_folder="web1" id="file17483944" filename="top-10-best-high-value-smartphone-budget-october-2019.html">
<p> Android News / Top 10 Best Value Smartphones You Can Buy Right Now – October 2019 </p>
<p> Top 10 Best Value Smartphones You Can Buy Right Now – October 2019 </p>
<p> The world of the high-value smartphone continues its relentless push forward with the launch of new flagships from OnePlus and Huawei, among others. But not everybody either wants to or can afford to spend an exorbitant amount of money on their next smartphone. </p>
<p> The reality is that there’s no real reason to spend the cost of a new computer on a smartphone either. Most smartphones above a certain price and value point will more than meet the needs of most users. The majority of those will be replaced by users with a new gadget within just a few years' time. </p>
<p> Fortunately, the technology keeps moving forward too, whittling away at the contrasts between a ‘premium’ device and a ‘budget’ device. That shift offers potential buyers a bit more flexibility when it comes to brands and models. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> But not every high-value smartphone is quite on par. There are still plenty of differences and caveats to consider for those looking for a great experience that suits their individual needs. Given the sheer number of OEMs and devices to consider, choosing one can be a daunting task. Here at Android Headlines, we do a lot of research and reviews to help make the decision easier. </p>
<p> That doesn't mean that every device that deserves placement here is going to have earned it. Device evaluations are subjective and there are dozens upon dozens of devices to select from. A significant portion of those may suit any single user's needs as well as the phones listed here. </p>
<p> With that in mind, here’s our take on the top devices available to buy now. Each offers a great value to users that we feel surpasses all others without breaking the bank. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> 10. Xiaomi Mi 9T </p>
<p> Anybody looking for an all-around great experience for around $300 is going to want to add the Xiaomi Mi 9T to their list. Not only does this 6.39-inch device sport an HDR-compatible AMOLED FHD+ (2340 x 1080) panel. That panel also packs in a fingerprint scanner and isn’t marred by notches, holes, or cutouts. Instead, the front-facing 20-megapixel snapper is hidden on a mechanical slider that activates only when it's needed. </p>
<p> That display is used to give users ready access to nearly stock Android 9 Pie — and later, it’s expected, Android 10. Powering that experience, apps, and everything else, Xiaomi incorporated a powerful Snapdragon 730 SoC coupled with 6GB RAM and 64GB storage. Conversely, the hardware’s powered by an 18-watt fast charging-compatible 4,000mAh battery. That should be more than enough to get just about anybody through a day on a single charge. </p>
<p> Those are all great features to have but aren’t the only features that are noteworthy here. The primary cameras Xiaomi placed in the Mi 9T’s gorgeous Flame Red, Glacier Blue, or Carbon Black frame are nothing to scoff at either. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> Xiaomi includes a triple camera array that all centers around a 48-megapixel wide-angle camera. Backing that up is a pair of snappers at 8-megapixels and 13-megapixels. Those are telephoto and 124-degree wide-angle lenses, respectively. 4K video capture and slow-motion at up to 960 frames-per-second are part of that package too. </p>
<p> So, where this handset is available, it's absolutely a solid choice in the high-value smartphone portion of the Android spectrum. </p>
<p> 9. Razer Phone 2 </p>
<p> Android gamers who don’t mind waiting on Android 10 — actually the sole reason this phone is ranked so low in this list — need to look no further than Razer Phone 2. The manufacturer only just got around to finishing the Android 9 Pie rollout. So the latest firmware isn’t going to be the biggest selling point here. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> But this is a phone that’s made explicitly to play the biggest titles available on mobile. It has plenty of design and software touches to back that up. </p>
<p> That all starts with last year’s flagship SoC, the Snapdragon 845. The chipset is older but still going to be among the strongest performers in any smartphone. Razer packed in 8GB of RAM too, along with 64GB of expandable storage. Providing power to the package is a 4,000mAh battery with both wireless and wired charging. </p>
<p> The specs listed there are all good and well but do nothing without a good display. So Razer topped all of that with a QHD 5.72-inch LCD panel. That HDR-compatible screen drives graphics at a refresh rate of 120Hz. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> Audio is on point here as well, propping up the experience further for gamers and making this a competition-ready phone. A large top and bottom bezel may seem a bit old school but dual front-firing speakers might just make up for that. Dolby Digital Plus 5.1 serves to make that all the more appealing. </p>
<p> For just $379 — down from a $799 MSRP — users also gain a customizable LED logo, dual 12-megapixel primary snappers, and an 8-megapixel selfie shooter in the IP67 rated frame. For a few bucks more on Amazon, buyers can pick up a silicone case or a screen protector bundled in too. The value here is high for smartphone gamers. </p>
<p> 8. Sony Xperia 10/10 Plus </p>
<p> At a respective price of just over $323 or $392, Sony’s Xperia 10 and Xperia 10 Plus will be the top high-value-focused Android smartphones for fans of the brand. Not only does it represent an initial effort bringing all of Sony’s previously tech separated divisions together. The company has also begun the process of updating some of these gadgets’ assets to Android 10. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> That means the hardware experience is well accented by a software experience that should be updated sooner than later with these Sony devices too. </p>
<p> On the former front, Sony has loaded up the Xperia 10 and 10 Plus with either a 6-inch or 6.5-inch FHD+panel. That’s featuring Sony’s tech to deliver cinematically accurate color in a 21:9 ultra-wide (or ultra-tall) format. The same joining of tech applies to Sony’s camera unit. The company includes a dual-lens 13-megapixel and 5-megapixel primary snapper with the latter being boosted to 8-megapixels with 2x optical zoom in the Plus variation. </p>
<p> Audio won’t be lacking either, thanks to DSEE HX and LDAC encoding being added by Sony’s audio division. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> A Snapdragon 630, with 3GB RAM in the Sony Xperia 10. 4GB memory back up a slightly more powerful Snapdragon 636 in the larger model. Both models have ample storage at 64GB. That’s expandable to 512GB via a microSD card. The battery capacity in either is either 2,870mAh or 3,000mAh, depending on the model chosen. </p>
<p> 7. ASUS Zenfone 6 </p>
<p> While the flagship-level ASUS Zenfone 6 was already held back by limited carrier capability, the state of availability for the smartphone has actually worsened since it first appeared on this list of high-value devices. No longer available via Amazon, users are going to have to turn to less-well-known sites if they want to pick on up. </p>
<p> At just $499, however, it still unquestionably belongs here among its high-value smartphone counterparts. </p>
<p> A dual-camera packing a Sony IMX 586 at 48-megapixels can be found at the back, which flips forward on a hinge to act as a selfie shooter. That leaves the entire front of the device, at 6.4-inches, to the gadget’s FHD+ Gorilla Glass 6 display panel. ASUS built Zenfone 6 around a Snapdragon 855 SoC with ‎6GB or 8GB RAM and 64GB, 128GB, or 256GB storage. Storage is expandable. </p>
<p> The camera is going to be the primary selling point since it’s a primary snapper instead of a selfie shooter. That includes all of the expected modes that come with the main camera on a modern smartphone. But the biggest advantage is going to be the quality that delivers for selfies and wide-angle selfies. That experience is going to arguably be second-to-none on the simple basis that it's the main camera taking the images. </p>
<p> But the ASUS Zenfone 6 earns its place here with its flagship specs above all else, priced well below the expected price point. It currently runs Android 9 Pie and is expected to receive an update to 10 too. So that’s only going to get better going forward. Or at least it will where it can still be purchased for use. </p>
<p> 6. Samsung Galaxy A50 </p>
<p> Samsung’s splash in the high-performance mid-range segment comes in the form of the Galaxy A-series. The devices are intended to set a bar for testing and experimenting with new features with a wider audience than its flagships typically draw in. Among the best of those devices is the Galaxy A50. </p>
<p> The Samsung Galaxy A50 continues falling in price, making it even more appealing. Last month it fell four dollars following a nearly $100 price drop before that. This month, that cost fell again to land at a starting point of just $238 on Amazon. Or, users can pick it up with a case and 64GB microSD card for just under $250. </p>
<p> Despite that price, the Samsung Galaxy A50 is a sum of plenty of top new features. That all starts with the in-display fingerprint scanner. A 6.4-inch slim-bezel Super AMOLED Infinity-U display tops that, delivering Android 9 Pie-based OneUI — expected to receive Android 10-based OneUI 2.0. </p>
<p> A feature-rich triple camera array adorns the back of this high-value smartphone. That comes complete with almost all of the same features found in the popular and reputation-building Galaxy S series. </p>
<p> Under the hood, that package is coupled with a larger than average 4,000mAh battery and in-house Exynos processor. </p>
<p> Three colors are available for this flagship-emulating handset. Those include a stately Black, Blue, or White. Samsung has ensured that each comes with ample RAM and storage to back the processor — on par or better than what most competitors in the cost bracket have available. </p>
<p> Fans of Samsung would do well to start their buying process by considering the Samsung Galaxy A50 or the next entry in place of its much pricier flagships. </p>
<p> 5. Samsung Galaxy A70 </p>
<p> Likely the reason for continued price drops for the Samsung Galaxy A50, the Galaxy A70 is a more powerful device following in the same vein. It’s also been getting its own price drops recently. In fact, it’s now available for $338.00 or just under a dollar over that, depending on the color that's picked. That’s nearly $30 cheaper than last month. </p>
<p> For that price, users are getting many of the same features as the Galaxy A50 via Samsung’s OneUI. That will be updated to a second-generation iteration at some point in the future but it’s the fact that the A70 is backed by considerably better hardware that sets it apart. </p>
<p> Here, users are getting the octa-core Snapdragon 675 SoC backed up by 6GB of RAM and 128GB of expandable storage. That’s double the capacity and 2GB more on memory than the smaller device. </p>
<p> The cameras are bolstered too, starting with the primary snapper. That sensor has been bumped from 25-megapixels to 32-megapixels. </p>
<p> Digging deeper under the hood, the 4,500mAh battery is 500mAh bigger thanks to the larger 6.7-inch display panel adding some room. That’s the same type of display found in the Samsung Galaxy A50 but 0.3-inches won’t go amiss for those who might need extra space. </p>
<p> All of those singularly minor updates stack to a much better device for comparatively little money. That high-value smartphone package is only made better by the fact that this is a Samsung-built device. As the world's top smartphone manufacturer, that brings a level of reputation not found with many competitors as well as plenty of support if anything does go wrong. Users can pick up the Samsung Galaxy A70 in Blue, Black, or White from Amazon. </p>
<p> 4. Moto Z4 </p>
<p> Motorola’s Moto Z4 is maintaining its position for three reasons. Chiefly, it’s because this device is 5G compatible, with some caveats. It’s also because of better specs than many competitors at high-value cost intrinsic in a top Android smartphone. Alongside that, there are some Pixel-like features and other value-added features too. </p>
<p> On the first of those highlights and the last, the Moto Z4 is a semi-modular handset. There are magnetic pins at the back which attach to add-on ‘moto mods’ to add functionality. The only available moto mod for 5G is through Verizon but as a leader in U.S. 5G, that’s not necessarily a bad deal. The somewhat expensive mod doesn’t take the cost quite as high as most competing 5G handsets. </p>
<p> Meanwhile, other mods extend things further. Mods exist for taking 360-degree photos, battery, projection, gaming, and more. </p>
<p> On software, Motorola has ensured the Moto Z4 is as close to stock Android as possible. The Lenovo-owned company didn’t take that quite so far as to enroll in the Android One program. Regardless, this handset will gain Android 10 at some point. </p>
<p> Part of the stock software includes a Pixel-like night mode that actually performs on a comparable level. That’s something not many OEMs have managed to match but Moto comes very close. The standard camera modes, conversely, shoot exceptionally well for a phone in this price bracket. </p>
<p> Driving the software, a Snapdragon 675 SoC, 4GB RAM, and 128GB of expandable storage are great to have. The average two-days of life via optimizations and an appropriately-sized battery are even better. </p>
<p> That’s all squeezed behind a 6.4-inch OLED display in a stylized frame that could only be a Moto. For just $499, the Moto Z4 can be had in either Frost White or Flash Gray. </p>
<p> 3. Nokia 7.2 </p>
<p> Now, Nokia didn’t go crazy when it iterated on its 7-series this year. The Nokia 7.2 is priced just above the previous iteration at $349.99 and effectively builds on everything great about the previous model. </p>
<p> To begin with, Nokia has kept its HD+ PureView display panel, powered by HDR 10-compatible technology. But that’s been boosted to a larger 6.3-inch full size and its large notch has been replaced by a dewdrop cutout. The camera above that has been taken up significantly to 20-megapixels. </p>
<p> Cameras at the back are improved but keep the same quad-pixel technology that made the 7.1 great. That’s a 48-megapixel primary snapper with an 8-megapixel wide lens and a 5-megapixel depth sensor. </p>
<p> Nokia used glass on both the front and back to create a truly premium in-hand feel but there are different colors this time around. Those are Charcoal Grey, Ice Silver, and Cyan Green. </p>
<p> On the inside, everything’s been pushed forward to prepare for near-stock Android 10. Nokia’s 7.2 is, like its predecessor, part of the Android One Program. So it should gain updates for a long time to come and quickly. The internal rework starts with a RAM boost with 4GB or 6GB options backed by up to 128GB storage. The storage can be expanded up to 512GB. </p>
<p> Nokia reinforced the memory and capacity to match the update to an octa-core Snapdragon 660 SoC. Battery life from the Nokia 7.1 was a multi-day affair and that should improve here with a bigger battery. The capacity is rated at 3,500mAh, up from the previous 3,060mAh battery. </p>
<p> Taken together, Nokia’s 7.2 is going to quite easily hold the device's place as a high-value Android smartphone worthy of its position in the segment. </p>
<p> 2. OnePlus 7t </p>
<p> OnePlus has now released a stellar update to its OnePlus 7. Dubbed the 7T, and costing just $599, the high-value new member to the company’s smartphone lineup can only be described as a flagship killer. </p>
<p> Although it's priced like a mid-range handset, the OnePlus 7T is a flagship through and through, fit to rival any other device on the list. There are dozens of reasons well beyond the price that value is so high for this smartphone. But everything starts with its update to a 6.55-inch, 90Hz “Fluid AMOLED” panel. That's HDR10+ with a peak brightness of up to 1,000 nits. </p>
<p> A nearly dead-even bezel surrounds that with a comparatively tiny waterdrop notch at the top. Underneath that facade — available in either Frosted Silver or Glacier Blue — the power provided by OnePlus 7T is exceptional. A revamped Snapdragon 855 Plus SoC underpins everything, backed by 8GB RAM. Storage doesn't fall short either at 128GB. </p>
<p> A 3,800mAh battery with 30W "Warp Charging" drives that hardware to deliver Android 10-based OxygenOS 10. That OEM variation on Android is widely touted as being better than stock while maintaining stock roots. So the OnePlus 7T should deliver an experience that's well worth the cost and then some. </p>
<p> Of course, all of that is stepping past one of this phone's most exciting aspects. Namely, those are its triple-arrayed 48 MP primary camera, 16 MP ultra-wide camera, and 8 MP 2X telephoto camera. </p>
<p> Enhancements to the now almost industry-standard Portrait and Night modes are present here. OnePlus also introduces a Macro mode capable of shooting at as close as 2.5 centimeters. The front camera is no slouch either at 16-megapixel with EIS, among other features. </p>
<p> 1. Google Pixel 3a/3a XL </p>
<p> In the leadup to this month’s announcement of the Google Pixel 4 lineup, Google’s budget-minded Pixel 3a lineup has seen price drops yet again. Or at least it has for most of those via Amazon. Available in Clearly White, Purple-ish, and Just Black, the cost is now going to depend on the version and color. </p>
<p> The Clearly White Pixel 3a, for instance, is holding its standard $399 price while the larger Pixel 3a XL in Purple-ish only fell by a few bucks to $459. Other versions are down but quite a bit more. The Pixel 3a price starts at just $349 while the larger XL device now starts at just $429. </p>
<p> Buyers are getting quite a lot for their money here too. One of the most solid mid-range Snapdragon processors around is included, alongside 4GB of RAM and 64GB storage, for starters. That’s an octa-core chipset driven by an 18W fast-charging 3,000mAh or 3,700mAh battery depending on which version is selected. Of course, that presents users with the fastest-updating stock Android available anywhere. </p>
<p> At 5.6-inches and 6.0-inches, the Pixel 3a and Pixel 3a XL both ship with FHD+ resolution OLED display panels. On the opposing side of that, the widely lauded camera features found in the larger flagship devices are packed behind similar sensors. Another sensor is embedded in the frame of the gadget that’s squeezable, adding more functionality. </p>
<p> There’s no glass rear-paneling and no IP incursion rating for Pixel 3a or 3a XL. There doesn’t seem to be any major software-based caveats like those initially found on the flagship counterparts either. Everything just comes together smoothly to present users with a near-perfect Pixel-branded Google-made Android experience in a seriously premium device at a low cost. </p>

<p> Top 10 Best Indian Android Smartphones – April 2018 </p>
<p> Quite a few flagship smartphones launched on a global scale in the last couple of weeks, but most of them are still not available in India. Devices like the Huawei P20 Pro, Xiaomi Mi MIX 2S, and the Xperia XZ2 are missing for just that reason, even though most of these phones (if not all of them) will arrive to the country in the near future. <p> 10. HTC U11 Plus </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> The HTC U11 Plus is still the company’s flagship handset, as the HTC U12 did not arrive just yet. The HTC U11 Plus was announced back in November, and it is made out of metal and glass, while it sports rather thin bezels. This smartphone is fueled by the Snapdragon 835 64-bit octa-core SoC, while it sports a 6-inch QHD+ display. The phone is IP68 certified, and it comes in both 4GB and 6GB RAM variants. A 12-megapixel snapper is included on the back of this smartphone, while you will find an 8-megapixel shooter on the phone’s front side. The HTC U11 Plus is available from Flipkart for Rs. 56,990 ($868), while you can also get it from Amazon.com for $669.99 (both are 6GB RAM variants). </p>
<p> The Xperia XZ1 is no longer Sony’s flagship handset, but the Xperia XZ2 is not yet available in the country. The device ships with the Snapdragon 835 64-bit octa-core SoC, 4GB of RAM and 64GB of expandable storage. A 5.2-inch fullHD display is included in this package, while the phone comes with a 19-megapixel camera. Android Oreo comes pre-installed on this device, while a 2,700mAh non-removable battery is also a part of the package. The Xperia XZ1 can be purchased for Rs. 42,400 ($646) on Amazon India, while it costs $485.53 on Amazon.com. </p>
<p> The Xiaomi Mi MIX 2S was announced quite recently, but the company did not bring it to India just yet. Having said that, its predecessor, the Mi MIX 2S is available. All the necessary links are available down below, and the phone’s pricing starts at $519 </p>
<p> The Honor View 10 is still the company’s flagship, though the Honor 10 is expected to arrive in a couple of days. The Honor View 10 is fueled by the Kirin 970 64-bit octa-core SoC, Huawei’s flagship processor, and the device sports a 5.99-inch fullHD+ display. The phone includes 4GB / 6GB of RAM and it comes with 16 and 20-megapixel snappers. A 13-megapixel shooter is included on the phone’s front side, while a 3,750mAh non-removable battery is also a part of the package. The device is available in India via Amazon, for Rs. 29,999 ($457). </p>
<p> The Samsung Galaxy S8 and S8 Plus are no longer Samsung’s flagship handset, but they still deserve to be on this list. These two devices are still amongst the best-looking smartphones out there, and they’re still plenty powerful. Both devices are fueled by the Exynos 8890 64-bit octa-core SoC in India, while they both sport 4GB of RAM. The Galaxy S8 ships with a 5.8-inch QHD+ Super AMOLED display, while the ‘Plus’ model sports a 6.2-inch QHD+ Super AMOLED panel. The Samsung Galaxy S8 can be purchased in India via Amazon for Rs. 46,034 ($701) at the moment, while the Galaxy S8 Plus costs Rs. 57,700 ($879). The two phones are priced at $597.75, and $639.98 on Amazon.com </p>
<p> The LG V30 Plus is still LG’s most powerful handset in India, as the LG V30S ThinQ did not make its way to the country just yet. Having said that, these two handsets are extremely similar, so the LG V30 Plus is still a great buy if you’re looking to get the latest and greatest from the company. The device is made out of metal and glass, while it sports a 6-inch QHD+ P-OLED display, 4GB of RAM and 128GB of native storage. The device comes with Android 7.1.2 Nougat, and LG’s custom UI, while it is fueled by the Snapdragon 835 64-bit octa-core processor. The phone is currently priced at Rs. 44,990 in India, on Amazon India, while you can get it from Amazon.com for $644.50. </p>
<p> The OnePlus 5T is the company’s flagship handset, as the OnePlus 6 still did not arrive. The OnePlus 5T is made out of metal, it sports really thin bezels, while it comes with a rear-facing fingerprint scanner. This handset also come with a dual camera setup on its back, and it sports a 6.01-inch fullHD+ Optic AMOLED display. The phone comes in both 6GB and 8GB RAM variants, while it packs in a 3,300mAh non-removable battery. The OnePlus 5T also supports fast charging, OnePlus’ proprietary Dash Charge fast charging technology, while the phone is upgradeable to Android 8.0 Oreo, and Android 8.1 Oreo is right around the corner. Both OnePlus 5T variants are available on both Amazon and GearBest, and all the necessary links are included down below. </p>
<p> The Google Pixel 2 and Pixel 2 XL are Google’s most powerful handsets to date. The two phones looks noticeably different due to their design, but they include rather similar internals. Both devices are made out of metal, with a hint of glass on the back, while both phones also include a really powerful camera on the back. These two phones, needless to say, come with stock Android, while both are fueled by the Snapdragon 835 64-bit octa-core processor, which was Qualcomm’s flagship processor for last year. The two devices are priced at Rs. 50,618 and Rs. 58,400 in India, respectively. You can buy these two phones from Amazon.com for $519.99, and $798.82, respectively. </p>
<p> The Galaxy S9 handsets are Samsung’s new flagship devices, but the Galaxy Note 8 is still more than a compelling choice. This handset is fueled by the Exynos 8890 64-bit octa-core SoC in India, while it comes with 6GB of RAM. The device sports really thin bezels, while it is made out of metal and glass, and it offers a dual camera setup on its back. A fingerprint scanner is also included on the back of this smartphone, and the device features a 6.3-inch QHD+ Super AMOLED display, with curved sides. The Galaxy Note 8 is priced at Rs. 67,900 in India (on Amazon), while you can get it for $794.95 on Amazon.com. </p>
<p> The Galaxy S9 and S9 Plus are the latest and greatest handsets Samsung has to offer. These two phones were introduced back in February, and they’re both made out of metal and glass. The Galaxy S9 and S9 Plus are fueled by the Exynos 9810 in India, while the two phones do resemble quite a bit, but the Galaxy S9 Plus comes with a dual camera setup on the back, and it’s more powerful in general, mainly thanks to extra RAM it packs in. The Galaxy S9 comes with 4GB of RAM, while the Galaxy S9 Plus offers 6GB of RAM. These two handsets are available both via Amazon India and Amazon.com, and all the necessary links have been included down below. </p>

<p> Top 10 Best Indian Android Smartphones – June 2018 </p>
<p> The OnePlus 6 joined our top 10 smartphones in India list, but other than that, the list remains more or less unchanged. Samsung’s flagship for last year is in fourth place, followed by two Pixel phones, and so on. Check out the list down below if you’d like to know more. </p>
<p> 10. Xiaomi Mi MIX 2S </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> The Xiaomi Mi MIX 2S is Xiaomi’s flagship along with the Xiaomi Mi 8. The Mi MIX 2S does not sport a display notch, unlike the Mi 8, and it’s made out of ceramic. The device comes with a 5.99-inch fullHD+ display, and Android 8.0 Oreo comes out of the box, with MIUI 9.5. Two 12-megapixel cameras are included on the back of the phone, while it utilizes a 3,400mAh battery. 6GB RAM Xiaomi MI MIX 2S is available for $479.99 from GearBest as we speak. </p>

The device sports 16 and 20-megapixel cameras on the back, while a single 13-megapixel camera can be found on the phone’s front side. Android 8.0 Oreo comes pre-installed on the Honor View 10, while Emotion UI (EMUI) 8.0 comes on top of Google’s OS. The Honor View 10 is priced at Rs. 29,999 ($445) in India, and it can be purchased from Amazon. </p>

Both phones feature a single camera on the back, while both sport curved displays. A rear-facing fingerprint scanner is included on both phones, and these two devices actually look the same as well, though the Galaxy S9 Plus is a larger phone. The Galaxy S8 and S8 Plus are now priced at Rs. 43,900 ($649) and Rs. 66,800 ($987) in India. </p>

The Nokia 8 Sirocco features a 5.5-inch QHD P-OLED display, 6GB of RAM and 128GB of storage. The device is fueled by the Snapdragon 835 64-bit octa-core processor, and it ships with Android 8.0 Oreo. The Nokia 8 Sirocco is now available via Flipkart and it costs Rs. 49.999 ($740). </p>
<p> The LG V30 Plus may not be the latest smartphone LG had introduced, but it is still one of the best ones, if not the best one. The LG G7 ThinQ came with a number of issues, which maybe makes the LG V30 Plus a better choice still, plus this phone is not that old, to begin with. The LG V30 Plus sports really thin bezels, it is made out of metal and glass, and it comes with a large 6-inch QHD+ P-OLED display. The phone features 16 and 13-megapixel cameras on the back, while it includes 4GB of RAM and 128GB of storage out of the box. The LG V30 Plus is priced at Rs. 44,990 ($665) in India, and you can purchase it via Amazon India. </p>

The Google Pixel 2 is now priced at Rs. 47,140 ($696) at Amazon India, while the Pixel 2 XL costs Rs. 54,999 ($812). </p>
<p> The Samsung Galaxy Note 8 is no longer the company’s flagship smartphone, but it is still right up there behind the Galaxy S9 and S9 Plus. The Galaxy Note 8 is made out of metal and glass, while it is fueled by the Exynos 8895 in India. The phone sports 6GB of RAM, and it comes with a 6.3-inch QHD+ Super AMOLED display. The Galaxy Note 8 is also IP68 certified for water and dust resistance, while it includes the company’s S Pen stylus. A 3,300mAh battery is included in the package as well, and the phone is now considerably more affordable than it was last year, the device is priced at Rs. 59,900 ($886) in India, and you can get it from Amazon India. </p>
<p> The OnePlus 6 is the newest addition to this list, the device was announced by OnePlus last month, and it has been available for a while now. The device is made out of metal and glass, it is fueled by the Snapdragon 845 64-bit octa-core processor, while it comes with 6GB or 8GB of RAM on the inside. The OnePlus 6 sports a 6.28-inch fullHD+ Optic AMOLED display, a 3,300mAh battery which is not removable, and a rear-facing fingerprint scanner. A dual camera setup is located on the back of this phone, while Android 8.1 Oreo comes pre-installed on the device, along with OnePlus’ OxygenOS. <p> 2. Huawei P20 Pro </p>
<p> The Huawei P20 Pro is the most powerful smartphone Huawei introduced thus far, it sports three cameras on the back, and all three cameras include Leica’s lenses. The phone features a 6.1-inch fullHD+ AMOLED display, 6GB of RAM and 128GB of storage. These two smartphones are currently priced at Rs. 55,699 ($824, currently unavailable) and Rs. 59,900 ($885) on Amazon India. </p>

<p> Top 10 Best Indian Android Smartphones – March 2018 </p>
<p> This month’s list of top 10 smartphones in India is quite similar to last month’s, with one major difference, the Samsung Galaxy S9, and S9 Plus handsets are now available, and listed here. The Galaxy S9 and S9 Plus actually managed to claim the very top spot on this list, and are followed by the Galaxy Note 8, and Google’s Pixel 2 smartphones. All of the devices listed here are available in India, so if you’re interested in purchasing a new smartphone in the country, or are just interested in checking out the list, read on. </p>
<p> 10. Sony Xperia XZ1 </p>

<doc url="https://www.androidheadlines.com/top-10-best-laptops-for-back-to-school-2020.html" parent_folder="web1" id="file17484760" filename="top-10-best-laptops-for-back-to-school-2020.html">
<p> Top 10 Best Laptops For Back To School 2020 </p>
<p> The time for back to school is inching ever closer and with it, our annual buyer's guide on the best laptops is here. </p>
<p> There are lots of different laptops to choose from these days whether you want something simple with great battery life or something powerful to handle all your PC needs and then some. You name it, we've got it here. </p>
<p> That being said, the best laptops for back to school are not going to be the same for everyone. So we've rounded up a good range of laptops with some variety in specs and purpose of use to cover everyone's bases. </p>
<p> Top 10 Best Laptops For Back To School 2020 – List </p>
<p> Best Laptop </p>
<p> Dell XPS 15 (2020) </p>
<p> When it comes to getting the best laptop overall for your back to school needs, Dell has your number as the XPS 15 continues to be one of the best laptops period. </p>
<p> This new 2020 version has a number of key highlights that make it a worthy successor. Not to mention a worthy laptop for all your classwork. </p>
<p> It's got stellar battery life which means you can rely on it to do work for you all day. Bring the charger or don't, because it should be fine without being plugged in until you get home. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> Of course it's also got one of the best looking displays on of any laptop on the market. Not just in this price range but in general. </p>
<p> With the Dell XPS 15 (2020) you're getting a 15.6-inch screen with 4K UHD resolution and it's nearly edge to edge. It's also powered by a 9th-gen Intel Core i7 CPU, and it has a GeForce GTX 1650 GPU so it'll even handle some gaming. Though there are better laptops for that. </p>
<p> You're also getting plenty of RAM with 16GB, and plenty of storage with a 256GB SSD. It only weighs 4 pounds too. Definitely light enough to carry around all day. </p>
<p> Best Laptop For Gamers </p>
<p> Razer Blade 15 Advanced </p>
<p> Razer is the king of gaming laptops with its Blade line for numerous reasons. And one of those is the extreme portability thanks to its sleek and slim design. </p>
<p> If you're a gamer headed back to school and you want one of the best laptops that allows you to do everything you need plus play games at peak levels, there's no better option than the Blade 15 Advanced. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> It comes with an NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2070 Super GPU so you can max out your settings on most games. All while keeping a relatively stable frame rate. </p>
<p> This particular model of the laptop also comes with 16GB of RAM (plenty for most of your gaming habits) and 512GB of storage. Though you can get get more in both of those areas for more money. </p>
<p> There's even the RTX 2080 Super model which comes with a 4K OLED display. Any way you slice it, this is a laptop that is perfect for any student who also plays games. It's your catchall laptop. </p>
<p> Best Budget Laptop </p>
<p> ASUS VivoBook </p>
<p> Not everyone is a gamer or has the extra income to blow out on a top-tier laptop for school. And while it is nice to have those things, it's not really necessary. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> If you just need a good laptop for back to school that allows you to complete your work, then the VivoBook from ASUS is your best option if you're on a budget. </p>
<p> It costs $249. So the entry point isn't much, and it comes with a respectable set of hardware specs for its intended purpose. It's got 4GB of RAM, 64GB of internal flash storage, up to 10 hours of battery life, and it runs on Windows 10 so it's compatible with a wide array of software. </p>
<p> Did we mention it's extremely portable? It weighs about 2.2 pounds and has an 11.6-inch screen. So it's not only lightweight but it fits easily into most bags or backpacks. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> You aren't going to be getting an absolute powerhouse here. But if that's what you need then there are other options on the list for that. This is definitely a great option for anyone who just needs a simple laptop that can do the basics. </p>
<p> Best Mid-Range Laptop </p>
<p> Acer Swift 3 (2020) </p>
<p> If you're looking for something a little more in the middle of the pack, the Acer Swift 3 2020 model is an option you should consider. </p>
<p> It comes with 8GB of RAM, a 512GB SSD, Wi-Fi6, and a nifty backlit keyboard for when you're up late working on coursework that needs to be turned in by 8am. </p>
<p> It also comes with integrated Ryzen graphics which is capable of playing games, but it is integrated graphics so you won't be turning all your graphics up on games to max. One neat trick that this laptop offers that others don't is the built-in Alexa support. </p>
<p> You can talk to Alexa right through the laptop with its integrated capabilities. Which means if you have other devices powered by Alexa around your room, apartment, or home, you can easily manage it by speaking to Alexa through the laptop. </p>
<p> The battery life is pretty decent as well at 11.5 hours. So you could keep it on the charger if you wanted to but you wouldn't need to as it should last you all day (basically through all of your classes). </p>
<p> Lastly it only weighs 2.65 pounds so it's not too heavy. Which means it's easy to cart around and one of the best laptops for back to school. </p>
<p> Best Laptop For Creators </p>
<p> Microsoft Surface Book 3 </p>
<p> This is the perfect laptop for creators. Whether your schooling deals with video production, music production, web design, or digital art, this will be powerful and versatile enough to handle everything. </p>
<p> When it comes to the performance, it has an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1660Ti GPU powering the graphics, and it comes with 32GB of RAM. That's more than enough to multitask and take care of all your applications. </p>
<p> This model comes with 512GB of storage, though you can bump that up if you need more. </p>
<p> One of the more useful functions is the ability to detach the display from the keyboard. In doing this you can use the laptop display like a tablet. Or you can detach the display and simply turn it around before attaching it again. This allows you to use it more like a touch display without having to hold it. </p>
<p> Microsoft says it has up to 17 hours of battery life. Which is definitely on the higher end of most laptops on this list. Basically, it'll last a long time. </p>
<p> Best Laptop For Battery Life </p>
<p> Dell Latitude 9410 </p>
<p> If your main concern is battery life, then this is the laptop you want. It's rated to last up to 27 hours on a charge. </p>
<p> That's an astounding amount of time for a machine with the specs that this laptop offers. Not to mention it can essentially last you two full days of use and then some if you were using it for about 10 hours a day. Or one full day if you used it for 24 hours straight. </p>
<p> Keeping that in mind, the battery life will certainly vary depending on how you use it. But however you use it, it'll still last longer than any of the other options on this list. </p>
<p> Battery life aside, the Dell Latitude 9410 also comes with 8GB of RAM, up to 2TB of hard drive space, a 14-inch screen, and it weighs about 3 pounds. This is a 2-in-1 laptop as well. So if the need arises you can flip the screen around and use the laptop in tent mode where you interact with just the touch display. </p>
<p> Best Laptop For Portability </p>
<p> Microsoft Surface GO 2 </p>
<p> If you want a full Windows 10 laptop option that's as light as it gets and is ultra portable, look no further than Microsoft Surface Go 2. Going back to school, you want something light and this is one of the best laptops for that. In fact it is the best option for portability. </p>
<p> Technically, this is a tablet PC and not a laptop. But because you can pick up the Surface Go 2 with the Type Cover keyboard dock (which is excellent by the way), and it comes with full Windows 10, it works like a laptop. </p>
<p> The screen is 10.5-inches. So it's small enough to fit in just about any bag pocket you would fit a school book in. Best of all, it only weighs about 1.25 pounds. Maybe a touch more with the Type Cover but still well below 2 pounds. </p>
<p> That makes it the lightest and therefore the most portable laptop option on this list. So if you're really looking for something that is easy to carry with you anywhere to the point that you can forget you have it, this is it. </p>
<p> This particular model comes with 8GB of RAM and 128GB of internal storage space, and is Wi-Fi only. An LTE option is available as well at a bit more money. The Type Cover also comes separate from the Surface Go 2, so that's worth keeping in mind. </p>
<p> Best Laptop For Apple Users </p>
<p> Apple MacBook Pro 13-Inch </p>
<p> So all of the laptops on this list have been Windows so far, but not everyone uses Windows PCs. If you're invested in the Apple ecosystem, then this is the one of the best laptops for you for back to school. </p>
<p> The most recent MacBook Pro with a 13-inch screen is pretty lightweight at just 3.1 pounds and it's just 15.6mm thin. And because of the 13-inch screen it's not very big either. Making it easy to stuff into a backpack or bag. </p>
<p> The display comes at a resolution of 2560 x 1600, with the laptop sporting a 10th-gen Intel Core i5 CPU. This particular laptop model also comes with a 1TB SSD for loads of internal storage, as well as 16GB of RAM for plenty of memory. </p>
<p> You can however dump the storage down to 512GB if you want to save a couple hundred bucks. It's also carrying Intel Iris Plus graphics, the backlit magic keyboard, the Touch Bar and Touch ID, and a battery life of up to 10 hours. </p>
<p> In short it can handle your school work and last for about a day off the charger, play some games, stream your movies and music and more. It'll be a solid choice with al of your favorite Apple services too. </p>
<p> Best 2-In-1 Laptop </p>
<p> HP Spectre X360 </p>
<p> 2-In-1 laptops can be highly underrated, but they're definitely worth your consideration because of their versatile configurations. </p>
<p> Use them like a regular laptop, or use them like a touch display with a kickstand. You can even flip the keyboard all the way back onto the back of the display and use the laptop like a tablet if you prefer. </p>
<p> So it more or less conforms to fit your needs instead of the other way around. The HP Spectre X360 is the best 2-In-1 around and aside from its versatility when it comes to configurations, it's pretty powerful too. </p>
<p> You get a 10-gen Intel Core i7 CPU, Intel Iris Plus graphics, 8GB of RAM, 512GB of storage via the SSD, a 13.3-inch display with a Full HD resolution, a fingerprint reader, and a battery life of close to 10 hours. It weighs just under 3 pounds (2.87 pounds), so it's fairly portable as well. </p>
<p> This is an all around great laptop and packed with nifty features if you need something that can be used in numerous configurations. </p>
<p> Best Chrome OS Laptop </p>
<p> ASUS Chromebook Flip C434TA </p>
<p> Chromebooks have come a long way over the years and are very capable laptops now. They were still decent in their infancy, but now they're much more equipped to be a solid replacement for something running on Windows or MacOS. </p>
<p> The ASUS Chromebook Flip C434TA sits at the top of the Chrome OS pack. And is available in multiple variations to fit your personal needs. The $599 model comes with 64GB of internal storage space, 8GB of RAM, a 14-inch display with Full HD resolution, and a pretty stellar battery life of up to 10 hours. </p>
<p> It's running an Intel Core m3 CPU, and although it can't play PC games traditionally, it can play games through Stadia. So this is still technically a good gaming machine if that's how you access your games. </p>
<p> This is also a 2-In-1 with a 360-degree hinge, and a touch display so you can use it like a tablet. Lastly it only weighs around 3 pounds. So while it isn't the lightest laptop of all the ones we've picked for this list, it's still very light and portable. </p>
<p> Making this one of the best laptops for back to school and the best Chrome OS option. </p>

<p> Top 7 Best Smartphones For Back To School 2020 </p>
<p> It's back to school season, even though it doesn't feel like it, and that means it's time for our annual buyer's guide on the best smartphones to pick up. While most kids are going to be staying home and doing classes online, a new smartphone is still going to be needed for a lot of people. There are lots of options available, as you might have expected. </p>
<p> We've rounded up the very best smartphones that you can pick up. Some of these are rather inexpensive, while others have the best battery life, the best camera, or just the best period. So there's something for everyone on this list. </p>
<p> Best smartphone </p>
<p> Samsung Galaxy S20+ </p>
<p> The Samsung Galaxy S20+ is one of the best smartphones to pick up for back to school, even though it might be overkill for most people. But because this is one of the latest and greatest smartphones out there, it will be a good one to use for many years to come. You'll likely get around four to five years out of this one. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> The Galaxy S20+ comes with a 6.7-inch Quad HD+ 120Hz display, powered by the Snapdragon 865 chipset with 12GB of RAM and 128GB of storage. It also sports a 4500mAh capacity battery that should keep you going all day long. Not to mention the fact that this also comes with 5G connectivity for all of the US carriers. This is also unlocked, so you can just pop in your SIM card and you'll be ready to go. </p>
<p> Best value smartphone </p>
<p> Google Pixel 4a </p>
<p> The Pixel 4a is the best value smartphone by a long shot. Coming in at just $399, you're getting a phone with one of the best cameras on the market. As well as the latest version of Android, pretty decent battery life, and of course the best of Google. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> Pixel 4a is brand new, it just launched this week in fact and you can read our review right here. </p>
<p> It sports a smaller 5.8-inch display, with the Snapdragon 730 chipset, 6GB of RAM and 128GB of storage to boot. There is a somewhat small 3140mAh capacity battery inside the Pixel 4a. Which does a good job of keeping the phone running all day long, without any real issues, though. </p>
<p> Best battery life </p>
<p> Moto G Power </p>
<p> The Moto G Power is a really great option if you need something that is going to last all day and then some. Motorola claims around three days on a single charge here. But for power users, that might be closer to two days. </p>
<p> There is a massive 5,000mAh capacity battery inside the Moto G Power that is going to last a very long time. It also sports a 6.4-inch FHD+ display, and the Snapdragon 665 which is going to help conserve that battery to last even longer. The TurboCharger is also included in the box, it charges somewhat slow at 15W, but that also means the battery is going to last longer. </p>
<p> Best for note takers </p>
<p> Moto G Stylus </p>
<p> The Moto G Stylus is a pretty decent smartphone, but Motorola has included a stylus with it – hence the name. And that makes it a really great option for those that like to take notes. </p>
<p> Like the Moto G Power, this sports a 6.4-inch FHD+ display, and the Snapdragon 665. There is also 4GB of RAM and 64GB of storage inside, that should give you plenty of storage. If not, there is also a micro SD card slot available for adding more storage. </p>
<p> While the battery isn't as big as the Moto G Power, the Moto G Stylus does also have a 4000mAh capacity battery that should keep it running all day long and then some. </p>
<p> Best quad-camera smartphone </p>
<p> Samsung Galaxy A51 </p>
<p> Who would have thought that you could get a quad-camera smartphone at this price? Well you can. And that's why the Galaxy A51 makes the list for the best smartphones for back to school. </p>
<p> The Galaxy A51 features a 48-megapixel main sensor, 12-megapixel ultra wide sensor, 5-megapixel macro and a 5-megapixel depth sensor. Allowing you to take just about any shot you want. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> It also sports a 6.5-inch FHD+ display, the Exynos 9611 chipset with 4GB of RAM and 64GB of storage. It's a really decent phone for the price, and having quad cameras definitely helps it out. </p>
<p> Best low cost smartphone </p>
<p> Nokia 5.3 </p>
<p> The Nokia 5.3 is a pretty incredible smartphone for the money – only $199. It is also unlocked and works on all of the US carrier networks. That includes AT&T, T-Mobile and Verizon. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> Nokia 5.3 sports a 6.55-inch HD+ display, the Snapdragon 665 with 4GB of RAM and 64GB of storage. There is also a micro SD card slot available and there is support for Adoptable Storage. </p>
<p> HMD Global has outfitted the Nokia 5.3 with a 4000mAh capacity battery that should keep this one running for two days or more. </p>
<p> This comes with Android 10, and it will get Android 11. Which is due to launch next month. Since this is an Android One device, it should get the update pretty quickly. </p>
<p> Best inexpensive flagship </p>
<p> OnePlus 8 </p>
<p> The OnePlus 8 is definitely the best inexpensive flagship, and one of only two smartphones on this list that has 5G support. </p>
<p> OnePlus 8 comes with a 6.55-inch FHD+ display, the Snapdragon 865 chipset, 8GB of RAM and 128GB of storage. It also has a 4300mAh capacity battery that does pretty well at keeping it going all day long. It also has Warp Charge 30T for some pretty quick fast charging. So even if it doesn't last all day long, you can charge it up pretty quick. </p>
<p> It also comes with a triple camera setup on the back. With a 48-megapixel main sensor, 16-megapixel ultrawide and a 2-megapixel macro sensor. So you can get some really incredible shots out of this camera setup. </p>
<p> It does also work with all three of the US carriers. Though it doesn't work with Verizon's 5G network, unless you buy it specifically from Verizon. </p>

<doc url="https://www.androidheadlines.com/2019/08/top-10-best-value-smartphones-budget-8-2019.html" parent_folder="web1" id="file17483964" filename="top-10-best-value-smartphones-budget-8-2019.html">
<p> Top 10 Best Value Smartphones You Can Buy Right Now – August 2019 </p>
<p> Choosing a new smartphone can be such a difficult task, especially when it comes to high-value smartphones. </p>
<p> With dozens of big manufacturers jostling to outdo others each passing year, only a handful of devices are deserving. Not all of them that might be worthy of a spot will land a placement, either. </p>
<p> Making matters more challenging, there is a growing gap between what smartphone manufacturers and smartphones users identify as price brackets. That's true for everything from the upper and middle brackets down to the budget end of the spectrum. Coupled with that discrepancy is a decreasing gap between those in terms of performance and features. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> Of course, deciding which devices truly fit the descriptor "the best" comes down at least in part to opinion. The devices listed here are readily available to purchase and work in most regions, if not all of them. </p>
<p> Some brands, such as Huawei, simply aren't recommendable right now for a variety of reasons. For example, the challenges Huawei faces are driving it to step back from Android as its primary operating system. Its smartphones also not widely available and its future partnerships remain in question. So it just won't be appearing here for the time being. </p>
<p> Here at Android Headlines, we spend a lot of time examining and testing nearly every new smartphone that hits the market. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> This list was built on a foundation of knowledge about reliability and other aspects that make for a truly great experience, pushing boundaries with respect to the value versus cost metrics. While not without subjectivity, it represents Android Headlines's top ten best smartphones falling below that ever-increasing "premium" cost barrier. </p>
<p> 10. Xiaomi Mi 9T </p>
<p> The Xiaomi Mi 9T is effectively the global variant of the Redmi K20 that launched in China back in May. Buyers can expect to pay just $300 on Amazon, it is primarily intended for Europe. There is also the possibility that it could work in the US — though not guaranteed and only on GSM carriers. That doesn't detract from its place among the best value smartphones around. </p>
<p> For camera and display gurus in the value segment, this is going to be an obvious stand-out. To begin with, that's because its 6.39-inch AMOLED FHD+ (2340 x 1080) panel is better-equipped than others in the segment. It also has a higher screen-to-body ratio than other devices because Xiaomi chose to use a pop-up camera. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> HDR content is supported as well as modern features such as an in-screen fingerprint scanner and 18-watt fast charging. </p>
<p> The front camera is a 20-megapixel snapper while the rear triple-sensor array includes a 48-megapixel standard wide-angle snapper, an 8-megapixel telephoto lens, and a 13-megapixel 124-degree wide-angle lens. For features during video capture, Xiaomi has incorporated 4K recording as well as up to 960 frames-per-second slow-motion capture. </p>
<p> Those who need internal specs and performance to match shouldn't be disappointed. This brings the same 6GB of RAM as others in the Mi 9 range and 64GB of storage. A 2.2GHz Snapdragon 730 SoC drives that and a 4,000mAh capacity battery powers the package </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> Style isn't left by the wayside by Xiaomi here either. The company offers this gadget in Flame Red or Glacier Blue with a fiery arrow gradient. A Carbon Black version is available as well. That features a carbon fiber aesthetic, true to its namesake. </p>
<p> 9. Nokia 7.1 </p>
<p> The Nokia 7.1 will likely receive a followup this year and is the oldest handset on our top ten best value smartphones list. At just $299 on Amazon, with consideration for what it brings to the table as one of Nokia's most premium gadgets ever, it's also still an exceptional handset. That's just $249 for the Blue variant while the higher price is for a Steel coloration. </p>
<p> Behind the notched 5.8-inch full HD+ PureView display, buyers of this Nokia gadget are gaining a healthy but not remarkable 4GB memory and 64GB storage. That's backing up a more-than-capable octa-core Snapdragon 636 SoC. Android 9 Pie fills out the experience. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> Android One is the big selling point here, setting aside USB-C, Bluetooth 5.0, a fingerprint scanner. Participation in the Android One program means that this device will receive plenty of updates to come both in terms of the operating system and security. Those should, in fact, be released on a timescale comparable to Google's own Pixel-branded handsets. </p>
<p> Android One also means a nearly-pure stock Android 9 Pie experience now with Android Q undoubtedly set to follow. </p>
<p> So despite only coming with reasonably decent cameras and moderate battery life, this is going to be a device that's still worth considering for those that don't want to spend quite as much as it will take to pick up other gadgets listed here. It also works with Verizon now, officially, so buyers aren't solely limited to those on GSM carriers any longer. </p>
<p> 8. Razer Phone 2 </p>
<p> Razer has built a reputation for gaming accessories and, more recently for gaming smartphones and add-ons related to that. It also happens to be listed at Amazon for $399.99, making it a prime fit in the value smartphone category. That only becomes a more prominent point with consideration for the over-$799 list price that seller gives the handset. </p>
<p> Looking past the price point, gaming is what this phone is very obviously for. A Snapdragon 845 SoC is nestled inside this smartphone's unique frame — built around two forward-firing stereo speakers. Razer packed in 8GB RAM and 64GB storage to back up the chipset. </p>
<p> The biggest drawback to that IP67 water-resistant design, despite being wireless charging-enabled, is its screen. </p>
<p> Advertisement </p>
<p> Now, the display does run at a mind-boggling 120Hz refresh rate but Razer chose an LCD panel rather than a newer OLED or AMOLED panel. So it isn't going to be quite as engaging as it might have been. It's 4,000mAh battery isn't necessarily going to be the longest-lasting either. Near-stock Android should help optimize the experience but that caveat is because it's made explicitly for gaming. </p>
<p> The addition of dual-12-megapixel snappers and an 8-megapixel shooter for selfies are just going to be the icing on the cake for anybody. For those who want a high-end gaming device on a budget, the Razer Phone 2 is the highest-value smartphones on the market. </p>
<p> 7. Sony Xperia 10/10 Plus </p>
<p> Sony finally brought its camera, display, and smartphone units together for smartphones this year under new management. The results of that, at the budget and mid-range side of things, are the Xperia 10 and Xperia 10 Plus. </p>
<p> These are also some of the tallest handsets around if not the tallest, making them only slightly niche. By the numbers, the screens are rated at a ratio of 21:9. Sony set the screen sizes at 6- or 6.5-inches depending on the model and both come with a full HD+ resolution, made expressly for media consumption. They also serve well when using multiple apps at the same time. </p>
<p> Beyond watching movies, a more 'cinematic' experience can be had with this handset'ss 13-megapixel, 5-megapixel primary snapper too. On the audio side, Sony's experts have delivered with Hi-Res Audio backed by DSEE HX and LDAC encoding from the company. The larger Sony Xperia 10 Plus bumps the second sensor to 8-megapixels and adds in 2x optical zoom </p>
<p> The Sony Xperia 10 and 10 Plus aren't identical in specs either. Respectively, they use the Snapdragon 630 and 636 SoCs, coupled with either 3GB or 4GB memory. Both feature 64GB storage. The batteries are rated at 2,870mAh or 3,000mAh. So these probably aren't going to be the longest-lasting handsets or the most powerful among the value smartphone offerings available. What they do deliver, in terms of standing out, are a great display and cameras. </p>
<p> 6. Samsung Galaxy A50 </p>
<p> In the current world of mobile technology, leaving aside budget-friendly Android handsets, Samsung is the world's second-largest manufacturer. Its "Galaxy A" series lineup is a testament to its longevity in the market, bringing together the budget- and mid-range handsets under a single umbrella. The Samsung Galaxy A50 is a nearly-perfect example of an everyday mid-range smartphone with all the latest tech in tow. </p>
<p> Previously featured on the Android Headlines list with a price tag of $350, this handset is going to be among the least expensive here. Depending on the intended region for sales, warranty status, and color, Samsung's Galaxy A50 can be purchased online as low as $268.99. </p>
<p> That's going to come with a respectable amount of memory and storage too, comparable to other devices here, regardless of which version is purchased. Under the hood, a powerful in-house Exynos processor is in use here too. </p>
<p> Now, for the money, buyers aren't necessarily paying for those features though. The "A" series is a testing bed for Samsung. </p>
<p> That means users are getting a decent dual-aperture camera array with a 4,000mAh battery. Over the top of that and delivering Android 9 Pie-based OneUI, there's a 6.4-inch Super AMOLED Infinity-U display with a waterdrop notch. </p>
<p> An in-display fingerprint scanner helps round out the premium features. For those who want a new Samsung without spending an arm and a leg, this could be the one to buy. </p>
<p> 5. Samsung Galaxy A70 </p>
<p> Stepping up from Samsung's Galaxy A50 is the company's A70, priced right around $360. The latest in Samsung's "A" series lineup, the Galaxy A70 boasts a Snapdragon 675 SoC joined with 6GB RAM and 128GB storage. That's compared to the 4GB memory in its more affordable sibling and equates to double the storage capacity. </p>
<p> Those aren't the only aspects that are better for just a bit more money though, although both should provide a similar experience. The primary camera in the Samsung Galaxy A70 has been bumped to 32-megapixels from 25-megapixels. The same screen style is in use but at 6.7-inches — for approximately 0.3-inches more real estate. </p>
<p> All of that is driven by a larger, faster-charging 4,500mAh capacity battery than can be found in its smaller counterpart. </p>
<p> This is a phone for those who want to spend a bit more for a slight boost almost across the board. While both smartphones represent a high value, the Samsung Galaxy A70 is going to be the better device from the top manufacturer on the planet. </p>
<p> 4. ASUS Zenfone 6 </p>
<p> Buyers looking for an amazing selfie experience without a punch-hole display or notches should not overlook the ASUS ZenFone 6. That's especially true now that it is officially supported in the US at a cost of just a penny under $500. </p>
<p> The first thing to be noticed about this device and its almost unremarkable design is that there's no camera to be found around its almost bezel-free 6.4-inch full HD+ Gorilla Glass 6 display. The primary camera is going to be the one a user accesses for selfies. </p>
<p> No second screen magic or guesswork is in place to make that possible, either. </p>
<p> A flagship-grade Sony IMX586 48-megapixel dual Quad Pixel snapper at the back of this device. The camera rests just above the fingerprint scanner mounted on a unique rocker mechanism. The rocker, at the touch of a button, flips that forward to any number of angles for quick and easy selfie shots complete with all of the specialty modes normally associated with the rear snapper on a smartphone. </p>
<p> That also means the display here is nothing to scoff at, at a screen-to-body ratio of 92-percent. </p>
<p> Under the hood, like the number two device on the list, 8GB RAM and 256GB storage designate this a flagship. So does the Snapdragon 855 SoC. While easy enough to purchase to be on our top ten value device list, limited carrier support and availability are primarily what hold this gadget from ascending here. </p>
<p> 3. Moto Z4 </p>
<p> Lenovo-owned Motorola's entry on this list is a gadget that has two major aspects setting it apart. Not least of all, at least on one carrier, the Moto Z4 is a semi-modular 5G-capable smartphone. For Verizon customers in the US who want bleeding-edge connectivity now rather than later, this $499 device is going to stand out among other smartphones on value. </p>
<p> The next big selling point is going to be that Android Q is, according to Motorola, a guaranteed update for the handset and that this smartphone is fully compatible with moto mods. At an extra cost, mods allow for a plethora of capabilities whether for photography, gaming, entertainment, connectivity, or much more. </p>
<p> A two-day battery and camera that comes close to approximating the Google Pixel's low-light photo mode round out the package. But those are hardly the only other noteworthy features. Aside from the 4GB memory, 128GB storage-backed Snapdragon 675 chipset, this smartphone also comes with an above-par display and a unique design that only 'Moto' could be responsible for. </p>
<p> 2. OnePlus 7 </p>
<p> From last month's listing, the OnePlus 7 — likely thanks to the overwhelming comparative favor shown the "Pro" variant — has been dropped in price yet again. It can now be purchased for just under $488 on Amazon. That's for the international variant. </p>
<p> Under normal circumstances, that wouldn't be enough for any device to hold onto its number two spot on our best value smartphones listing. Put frankly, the real benefit from that for consumers is that this technically isn't a mid-range device. </p>
<p> The OnePlus 7, for starters, features 8GB RAM and 256GB storage. That's backing the current top-of-the-line flagship chipset, the octa-core Snapdragon 855. That makes it, in a word, a flagship. </p>
<p> For drawback to this device, the biggest is its camera. That is now fixed via software updates but doesn't quite live up to its larger counterpart or the current number one value in smartphones. </p>
<p> There's also no guarantee since OnePlus doesn't seem to actually mention the gadget on the official US store site, that it will see any kind of real support for users in the US. There certainly isn't any warranty stateside for the variant that's currently priced at the above-mentioned low entry point. If those things don't matter, OnePlus 7 is going to be the best that money can buy for now. </p>
<p> 1. Google Pixel 3a/3a XL </p>
<p> Google's Pixel 3a and Pixel 3a XL are a return to near-Nexus form compared to flagship devices from the search giant. That's chiefly because the more 'premium' handsets have been met with staunch criticism and plagued with seemingly unending problems. By contrast, the series is a mid-range family of devices that will suit just about anybody. It does that without compromising where it's going to matter most to Pixel loyalists — namely, the cameras. </p>
<p> On software and hardware alike, the Pixel 3a and Pixel 3a XL come equipped with the same best-in-class features as their much more expensive siblings. Simultaneously, Google has equipped the handsets with one of Qualcomm's best octa-core mid-range SoC with plenty of memory and storage. </p>
<p> Google kept most of the stylings of the larger, more expensive counterparts too. Key differences include the abandonment of the divisive notch and the return of the headphone jack. The latter feature is one that Google entirely dismissed for its Pixel 3 and 3 XL. </p>
<p> All of that is jammed into either a 5.6-inch or 6.0-inch smartphone with a fullHD+ resolution OLED display and a squeezable frame for added functionality. A respectable 3,000mAh or 3,700mAh battery powers the package too. For $399 or $479, what buyers get is the purest Android 9 Pie — and soon Android Q — experience around. At those prices, these smartphones simply ooze value. </p>
